div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,242] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JULY 17, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD
div.p: BREMEN.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.
For Particulars see Advertisement below.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Suez about July 28
R.M.S "Ormuz" will leave Suez about August 11.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about August 1
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG, via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

HOMEWARDS. To NAPLES, GENOA, MARSEILLES, LISBON, ROTTERDAM, HAMBURG.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.
East African Line.
To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about July 4 and August 3.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamers leaves Alexandria on or about July 3, 17 and 31.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905
Ask for
Brewed at Wrexham England
Wrexham Lager Beer Co. Pilsener
Registered Label
And if not supplied apply to
John B. Caffari
Alexandria & Cairo

div.head: Daily Weather Report
div.p: Observations by Survey Department

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: There has been little or no change in the weather since Saturday, the wind being steady from the N.W. It is now inclined to veer to the eastward, with a rising barometer.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum.Six months P.T. 186 1/2 (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.- P.T. 4 per line. Mi- nimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news cloumns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisments.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques can be made payable to the Editor and Manager Rowland Snelling, Alexandria
London Office: 36, New Broad street, E.C.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English daily newspaper, established in 1880.
Editor and Manager: R Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, July 17, 1905.

div.head: THE FLEETS AT BREST.
div.p: The visit of the British Fleet to Brest and the hearty reception accorded to our sailors by their gallant hosts bring into a very pleasant prominence the question of our relations with our Continental neighbours. It was not always so. The period of misunderstanding and ill-feeling, though it may take an effort to recall it in the light of the present rapprochement, is still so near to us that an element of surprise inevitably mingles with the thankfulness that we feel for the complete and, we hope, permanent change. For this change we are indebted not a little to the tact of our King, so amiably reciprocated by the visit of M. Loubet; and both nations have felt and expressed their pleasure at the diplomatic strength given to the union.

Under the present circumstances the visit of our ships has a peculiar interest. The Continent of Europe contains explosive elements, to say nothing of the causes of mutual offence which are so widely scattered over the face of Europe and Asia, which no amount of friendly words render innocuous. The strong man

armed must continue to be the ultimate ga- rantee for the safety of his house. But it is possible to distinguish between nations whose interests and whose ambitions are fundament- ally hostile to ours, and nations with whom we have only some passing though irritating occasion of difference. And we must remember that for nearly five and thirty years it has been the object of one of the Great Powers of Europe to sow the seeds of discord between her rivals, and to profit by maintaining a perpetual state of irritation between peoples who might other- wise have rested in peace and tranquillity.

The ingenious attempt to weaken the entente which even the peacable M. Jaurés denounced with the vigour of a militant patriot should be as much a lesson to us, as were the earnest and successful efforts made by France to keep the peace without sacrificing her prestige or her exceptional position in Morocco. Whatever diplomatic success German interference in Morocco may have won, the understanding between France and England is in no way weakened and the visits of the Squadrons are, we hope, a sign that external interference can only tighten the bonds between the two great democracies of Western Europe. Admiral May's message to the French Minister of Marine expresses with nautical frankness what politicians have at times ignored, viz., the community of interests between the two nations who find themselves face to face with a formidable and hungry rival.

Although we are within a few weeks of the centenary of the last great sea fight between an English and a French fleet, and although in another ten years there will have been a full century of peace to seperate us from the great French war, yet it cannot be denied that peace between France and England has often been in sore peril during the intervening years. Indeed it seems but yesterday-and it is but little more than two years ago-that war was openly talked of between the two countries. And yet there can be no possible doubt as to the absolute sincerity of th joy with which both nations have welcomed the happy change which has come over the spirit of their mutual relation. The population of Brest and the crowds of visitors to the grim, grey old Breton port are as glad to see their British guests as the people of Portsmouth will be to welcome the French sailors when they pay the return visit. The fact is that there is no good reason, at this time of day why England and France should not live in peace and amity-while there are diverse very weighty reasons why they should. Nowhere, too, is that more keenly felt than on the French coast, whose people have ever had to bear the brunt of an English war. So Brest is right glad to-day-and so are we.

div.head: TROUBLES IN CRETE.
MARTIAL LAW THREATENED.
div.p: ROME, June 15. Reinforcements are leaving for Canea. (H.)

CANEA, July 16. The foreign Consuls in Crete have inter- viewed the insurgent leaders, and declared that, while the rebellious movement continues, it will be impossible to modify the status of the island. They promised to introduce the widest reforms, and demanded that the insurg- ents should lay down their arms within fifteen days, otherwise they might be forced to apply martial law. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE ENTENTE CORDIALE.
A "REAL" ENTENTE.
div.p: PARIS, July 16. Before leaving Paris, Admiral May wrote a letter to Mr. Thomson, Minister of Marine, saying that the "entente cordiale" was a real entente as French and English interests are identical (Havas.)

div.head: THE MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
div.p: LONDON, July 16. Great Britain and Spain will join the Mo- rocco Conference, provided that the programme be communicated to them in advance. (Reuter.)

div.head: DEATH OF A SPANISH STATESMAN.
div.p: MADRID, JULY 15. M. Villaverde, Spanish Conservative states- man, and ex-Premier, is dead (Reuter.)

Senor Villaverde made his mark in the first Silvela Administration in 1899 as the kind of statesman Spain needs. While his chief was engaged in sketching ecstatic visions of the Spain of the future the Finance Minister devoted himself to the securing of sufficient revenue to meet the national obligations and carry on the system of Government. The new supplies came in, but his efforts to se- cure a permanent reduction of outlay provoked violent hostility both in the army and navy, nor was this hostility bought off by the retire- ment of the Finance Minister, whose most important success was the raising of a loan of £48,000,000 to pay off the floating debt. His successors were only too glad to attempt in detail what he had endeavoured to achieve on a large scale. Persisiting in his mission to impress on his countrymen a rigorous system of economy Senor Villaverde gained so much ground that he was invited to form a Cabinet in 1901 and though unsuccessful that year became Prime Minister in 1902, resigning in the summer of 1903.

div.head: A RUSSIAN ROUT.
BRISK FIGHTING.
RUSSIANS DRIVEN NORTHWARDS.
div.p: TOKIO, July 15. Marshal Oyama reports brisk fighting in Sakaline. The Japanese drove out the Russians from Vladimirovka and Blijineye on the 10th inst. The Russians retired nortward to a fortified position at Dalineye, which the Japan- ese stormed and carried on the 11th, completely routing the russians on the 12th. (Reuter)

TOKIO, July 16. The Russians in the north of Korea are gra- dually being driven northwards. They now hold only two positions south of Tumen, viz., Fumen and Moshan. The latest information, however, reports the advent southward of a large force from Vladivostok, but it is believed that it will halt at Notiefok, north of Tumen, and make a resolute stand there against the Japanese advance. (Reuter.)
TOKIO, July 16. The rainy season has set in Manchuria, preventing movements on a large scale. (R)

div.head: THE PEACE CONFERENCE.
M. WITTE'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: TOKIO, July 15. Japan is gratified by the appointment of M. Witte, who will leave St. Petersburg on Wednesday and proceed to New York via Cherbourg. (Reuter)

WASHINGTON, July 15. Yesterday, Mr. Takahira visited President Roosevelt at Oyster Bay in connection with the details of the peace conference. He ex- pressed his gratification at the appointment of M. Witte, who is an able man, and who will lend confidence and weight to the conclusions of the conference. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, July 15. M. Witte, Russian peace plenipotentiary, will leave for Washington on the 19th inst. (Havas)

div.head: RUSSIAN PEASANT DISTURBANCES.
METHODS OF REPRESSION.
div.p: LONDON, July 16. Reuter's Agency learns from Odessa that the authorities are acting severely to repress the peasant disturbances. At Kherson 1,060 people have been arrested, and in the district of Parutino the prisoners have been terribly beaten by the Cossacks, and two have succumb- ed. Drastic measures have been taken, which are apparently successful. (Reuter)

div.head: DISAFFECTION OF COSSACKS.
MUTINY NEAR LODZ
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, July 15. A company of Cossacks at Zgierz near Lodz mutinied, complaining of their food, and demanding arrears of pay. They were surround- ed and disarmed. This is the first time that Cossacks have shown dissafection. (Reuter)

div.head: LEAVES SPAIN FOR AUSTRIA
div.p: PARIS July 15. M. Deroulède has refused the pardon, and declines to return unless he receive justice. (R)
MADRID, July 15. M. Deroulède is leaving for Austria. He has visited the King and Queen Christina, who received him cordially.

div.head: BEET-ROOT CULTIVATION IN PERSIA.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, July 15. It is stated here that, in compliance with the request of Persia, a commission of Russian sugar specialists will start in August to examine the possiblity of the cultivation of beet-root in Persia.

div.head: CARLISLE ELECTION.
div.p: LONDON, July 15. Carlisle election in place of the late Speaker, Mr. Gully. Mr. Chance, Liberal 3,616; Mr. Sanderson, Conservative, 2,585. (Reuter.)

div.head: GROUNDING OF CALEDONIEN.
div.p: ZEILA, July 15. The Caledonien, from China to Marseilles, badly grounded near here, has been pulled off by H.M.S. Perseus, which is towing her to Djibouti. (Reuter)

div.head: ARMY INSPECTIONS ABROAD.
div.p: LONDON, July 15. The Duke of Connaught announced at Bisley that he intends to make tours of inspection in South Africa and Canada. (Reuter)

div.head: SCOTLAND WINS ELCHO SHIELD.
div.p: LONDON, July 15. Scotland won the Elcho Shield. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: LONDON, July 15. Eton v. Harrow drawn. Surrey beat Wor- cestershire by 343 runs. The rest of the matches for this day were drawn. (R)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Rod el Farag district of Cairo during the night of Wednesday and at daylight on Thursday will be poisoned by the police.
TO POINT A MORAL. I.-A youth named Sabir Khalil, aged 16 years, attempted a free ride on a tram, with the result that, in leaping off to avoid the guard, he broke his left leg.

TO POINT A MORAL. II.-A boy named Hanna Bali, while flying a kite from the roof of a house in the El Baktaria quarter, fell through an opening and broke his right arm, besides sustaining minor injuries
LIFONTI'S MUSIC STORES have been removed from the premises in Cherif Pasha street to the new Lifonti Building in Rosetta road. The inauguration of the new establishment will take place in a few days.

SUEZ CANAL.-21 vessels passed through the Canal on the 13th and 14th int., 16 of which were British, 1 French, 4 German. The receipts for the two days were frs. 614,920.32, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 4,127,890.17

HOTEL BEAU-RIVAGE.-A successful small dance was given at this delightfully situated hotel on Saturday evening. The new floor which has been laid on the terrace was in the pink of condition, and the music was supplied by the string band of the Royal Berks. Before the dance a large number of dinners were served on the terrace.

SAN STEFANO CASINO.-The small dance given at the Casino on Saturday was very animated, a large number of people staying after dinner. Yesterday morning's instrumen- tal concert on the terrace was very largely attended, as usual. Massenet's fist suite d'orchestre was well executed, as was also Beethoven's fifth symphony, which was greatly applauded. Next Sunday, three singers from Milan will make their debut. THeir repertoire consists of selections from Italian operas. They will by accompanied by the orchestra.

EDEN MUSIC HALL FRACAS.-Last Friday, at about midnight, a quarrel broke out in the Eden Music-hall. It appears that the attitude of a part of the audience towards one of the artistes provoked heated replies; a scuffle ensued, and the confusion was increased by one of the performers, a Frenchman, falling in a fit. Had matters terminated ther, there would have been nothing further to comment upon, but we regret to state that Saghco- lagassi Lynn of the Police and Fire Brigade, who was present, seems to have made con- fusion worse confounded by unnecessarily drastic measure, which included the calling in of a number of policemen who were order- ed to draw their sword bayonets. Though it seems, so far, that no serious injuries were received in the affray, some French and other foreign subjects were hustled, and M. Gaston, M. Sinadino's chauffeur, brought away some nasty bruises. An inquiry was opened at the Gouvernorat at 3 p.m. on Sat- urday, a delegate of the French Consulate, to which complaints had been addressed, being present. After a close investigation of the facts it was finally decided that all papers re- ferring to the affair should be forwarded at once to the Ministry of the Interior, and that Saghcolagassi Lynn should in the meantime be suspended from the exercise of his functions.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt.-Col. C.J. Markham and officers, the band of the 1st Batt. King's Royal Rifles will perform the following programme of music at the Esbekieh Gardens to-morrow (Tuesday), commencing at 9 p.m.
1 Overture-"Don Juan"-Mozart
2 Valse, Lente-"Traumbild"-Von Blon
3 Pasquinade-....-Gottschalk
4 Selection (No 3)-"Il Trovatore"-Verdi
5 Euphonium Solo-"Serenade"-Schubert (Soloist Cpl.Geo. Steer)
6 Ballet Music-"Faust"-Gounod
7 Intermezzo-"Cavalleria Rusticana"-Mascagni
8 Marche-"Lorraine"-Ganne
Regimental March-Khedivial Anthem
God save the King, Thomas Brown, Bandmaster

div.head: ENGLISH PENSION, ITALIAN RIVIERA.
div.p: The best halfway home between Egypt and England is VIAREGGIO. near PISA.
Main line expresses stop. Fine woods, Sands, Sea bathing mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelly. Ever home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens.
Proprietress. English Ladies

div.head: THE FRENCH FETE.
THE CAIRO CELEBRATIONS
div.p: The festivities held in Cairo on Friday last in celebrations of the 14th of July, were, as we reported on Saturday last, a greater success than ever. The Sharia Kamel, the principal street of the Capital, assumed an appearance of unusual gaiety throughout the day, and though none of the shops were closed, it appeared to be an occasion of holiday-making for many of the French patriots. A number of the larger houses and establishments were de- corated with the tricolour, and after dark many of them were simply but effectively illuminat- ed. Amongst the chief of these we might men- tion the offices of the Gas Company, Shepheard's and the Continental HOtels, the French Agency and French Consulate, and the Cercle Fran- çais.

Receptions were held at 9 in the morning at the French Consulate by M. Bosquet, and at the Agency by M. Bonin, and it is needless to add that both of these notabilities received their many callers with their usual grace and courtesy.

Towards sunset Sharia Kamel became great- ly crowded, and when the triumphal arch which had been erected at the Boulac entrance to the gardens was illuminated, all the passers-by stood still to admire it. From the centre of the arch colourless electric globes had been arranged in rays, on the top of the two columns were similar lights set in circles, and between them hung chains of coloured globes.

On entering the gardens one passed along an avenue of short columns, each one of which, bearing the French arms, was brilliantly lighted, and this led to the special pavilion which had been erected for the reception of the guests by M. Bonin, who is representing M. de la Boulinière during the latter's absence.

To describe the scene which here met the eye is a task of no little difficulty. The pavilion was surrounded by a long string of Chinese lanterns, the ends of which were attached from the roof to columns some 8 feet in height. The pavilion was lit by electricity and its walls were prettily decorated with the French arms. To the right was a special open-air theatre which had been erected for a variety perfor- mance by which the troupe of the Nouveautés attracted many people, and also two bandstands for the accomodation of the bands of the Inniskilling Fusiliers and the Egyptian Cavalry, and between these two stands was an asphalted space which was reserved for dancing later in evening. In front of these gas jets had been arranged in various designs, which afforded an exceedingly pretty contrast to the Chinese lanterns, and on each side of the theatre was an arch of coloured electric globes.

M. Bonin, on his arrival, was met at the gates by the members of the committee and was greeted by the playing of the "Marseillaise" by the Egyptian Cavalry Band. On his ap- proaching the pavilion the band of the Innis- killing Fusiliers greeted him with the same strains, and as he entered, the string band in attendance continued the hymn. Next followed the Khedivial Anthem and after that "God save the King," both of which were played by the three bands in succession.

The British nation was not only very fully represented by those who had come primarily in an official capacity, but nearly every Eng- lishman who is in Cairo had come to take part in the fête, and the bond of union which the "Entente Cordiale" has established between the two races was in great evidence.
The large number of invited guests were received by M. Bonin with his usual cordiality, and every hospitality was pressed upon them by the members of the French colony who assisted him.

The two military bands performed their task with great credit, and their varied pro- grammes were greatly enjoyed by all present. The Nouveautés troupe, under the direction of M. Lauri, gave their usual performance, Mlle Mary Fleur, Mlle Liliane and M. Stephano being especially deserving of the applause with which they were wlecomed.

The pyrotechnic display was commenced about 11.30 p.m. It was exceedingly unfor- tunate that the fireworks had become damp, and that in consequence the set-pieces were by no means so good as they should have been in their effect. Heavy clouds of smoke almost hid them from view and choked the spectators, but the smaller pieces left nothing to be desired either as regards brilliancy or noise caused by the explosion, which was almost deafening. After the display of fireworks had been concluded, dancing was indulged in by many, the music being supplied by the military bands, and this was kept up for a cosiderable time. Two o'clock witnessed the departure of a large number of people, but it was not until after 4 p.m. that Cairo had assumed its usual early morning calm.

The committee to whom had been entrusted the work of organisation must indeed feel very happy at the success with which their efforts were crowned. All present enjoyed themselves immensely, and the unanimous opinion was that a more enjoyable evening could not have been wished for. We therefore do not hesitate to offer the committee, on behalf of our readers, their best thanks for the admirable way in which they performed their task and our heartiest congratulations on the results

The police authorities must also be con- gratulated upon the order which was maintain- ed among the large crowds which were attracted by the illuminated arch, and the streams of people which poured into the garden until a late hour. The carriage traffic was enormous, but the people were confined to the footpaths as far as possible, and we believe that in spite of the great crush no accident occurred.

div.head: THE ST. KILDA.
INCIDENT AT PORT SAID.
div.p: The Marseilles correspondent of the "Jour- nal" sends the particulars of a statement made to him by the captain of the St. Kilda, who arrived at that port on board the steamer Egypt, aecompanied by the oficers and the European crew of his vessel. After describing how the St. Kilda was sunk by the Dnieper and the crew were taken on board the cruiser, the captain of the British steamer continued:

"On our arrival at Port Said...the commander of the Dnieper told us that he in- tended to take us to Russia. 'We shall only wait to take in coal,' he said,'before proceeding on our voyage. You are our prisoners.' But one of us managed to escape, and informed the British consul of what had happened. The captains of two English men-of-war, the Lancaster and the Suffolk, came on board the Dnieper with the British Consul, and demanded our release.

"The commander of the Dnieper refused to accede to the demand of the Consul, who left the ship, accompanied by th ecommanders of the Suffold and the Lancaster, after stating that special measures would be taken if the British subjects were not set at liberty within an hour. A quarter of an hour later, when the Lancastor raised anchor as if she were about to approach the Dnieper, the Russian commander gave us permission to leave the ship, taking with us our luggage."

div.head: RUSSIAN TRANSPORT AT SUEZ
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Suez, Sunday

The Russian transport Anadyr arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon and entered the Canal at 10 p.m. bound to Libau. This vessel had been following Admiral Rodjestvensky's squadron, and although she did not take an active part in the great naval battle, she was present when the attack began and sub- sequently managed to escape, after rescuing several Russian officers and men from a sinking cruiser, who are now on board.

div.head: BRITISH BATTLESHIPS AT SUEZ.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Suez, Sunday
H. M.'s battleships Ocean, Centurion, Albion, and Vengeance arrived at Suez at daybreak this morning from the China station and entered the Canal at 10.30 this forenoon,

div.head: THE 14TH JULY AT SUEZ.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Suez, Saturday

The frenche fête this year was a great success at Port Tewfik owing to the excellent arrangements made by the committee. At 5 p.m. a Gymkhana commenced with chil- dren's races, and subsequently several other amusing games took place. Shortly after 9 o'clock in the evening, a dance was held and was attended by almost all the European community. It was gaily kept up to a late hour, to the strains of a string band. The fireworks, combined with the brilliantly illu- minated avenue, made a fine show.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending the 15th inst., 33 deaths from cattle plague were notified in Egypt. Of these cases one occured at Cairo, one at Port Said, one at Facous, 6 at Hehia, 14 at Chibin el-Kom, one at Ghizeh, and 10 at Beni-Souef. The number of deaths during the corresponding period last year was 874. The total number of deaths since the commence- ment of the epidemic amounts to 147,354, distributed as follows:-Gouvernorats, 893; Lower Egypt, 54,214, Upper Egypt 92,247.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: The weekly bulletin published by the Sa- nitary Administration concerning bubonic plague reports the notification of 12 cases of bubonic plague during the week ending Satur- day last. Of these cases, 7 occurred at Alex- andria, one at Kafr Zayat, 2 at Achmoun, and 2 at Damanhour. Nine deaths were reported, namely, 4 at Alexandria, one at Port Said, 2 at Achmoun, one at Damanhour, all of which are natives, and one European at Damanhour. Five cures have been effected and there remains 22 cases under treatment, namely, 2 Europeans and 6 natives at Alexandria, 7 natives at Achmoun, 4 at Toukh, one at Zifta, one at Kafr Zayat, and 1 at Damanhour.

Since the issue of this bulletin we learn that the case which occurred at Kafr Zayat has ended fatally, and that another member of the same household has contracted the disease. Both of these cases, we are told, are from Da- manhour.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Mors liner Tabor sailed yesterday morning for Havre viâ Malta with passengers, mails, and cargo of beans.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.

div.head: THE HAMADE INCIDENT.
ITS POLITICAL BEARINGS.
div.p: (FROM A CORRESPONDENT).

The corrupt administration of the late Vali of Beyrout had culminated in the sanguinary skirmish between Christians and Moslems two summers ago that threatened to develop into a wholesale massacre. The advent of the present Vali, Khalil Pasha, with all his moderation, integrity, and general enlightenment, did not soon dissipate the restlessness that continued in Beyrout after the fanatical outbreak, and it took some time before a normal course of things was re-established and a reasonable understand- ing between Christians and Moslems was attained. But Beyrout seems to be doomed to continual unrest. We had scarcely begun to taste the quiet delights of security when the Hamadé incident came to trouble our peace.

At one time it seemed to be the foreboding of a reign of terror, for the arrest of Hamadé Bey was followed by the ransacking of the Moslem Onsi library, and a few Moslem and Christian houses suspected of containing revolutionary documents. This attempt on per- sonal liberty, which even in Turkey is now considered a sacred right, has been deeply resented by all thinking Moslems. The recent sweeping movement of racial independence on the part of the Arabs in Yemen, with all its glamour of ancient Moslem glories, was calcula- ted naturally to evoke strong though silent sympathies in the hearts of their Moslem kinsmen on this side. The educated are begin- ning to realise the unfitness of the Turk to rule them, and chafe against his haughty demeanour towards them, while they resent his exclusive monopoly of Government offices. As for the poor and illiterate, they cannot but feel a stifled hatred of those who so mer- cilessly oppress and bleed them. But the lack of unity and homogeneity of race have always barred the possibility of any organised move- ment for freedom, while the adoption by the diplomatic Turk of the faith of the conquered, if only in form, has always acted as a strong magnet that drew Islam to the Sultanante, de- spite the repellent forces of despotism and oppression.

Yet the recent events in Yemen have chang- ed the aspect of things and inaugurated a new era in the political life of Islam, having served to stir latent dreams in the bosoms of the Syrian Arabs and fuse the heterogeneous elements of Islam in Syria into one common feeling of religoius and racial solidarity, that only blood and the old fascination of the sword and the emblematic banner could evoke. The tie of religion that has so far given the illusion of brotherhood between the Turks and Arabs (otherwise so far apart in language and genius), has at last become loosened, and the process of disruption is being slowly accom- plished at least in feeling, if not in fact. For- merly, no Moslem would confess to his hatred of the Turk or his wish for the disappearance of his rule, but lately such confessions have not been uncommon and have been more freely made to me as an Englishman and stranger on his travels. This ferment could not elude the attention of even the dull and obtuse Turk, whose suspicions were more especially aroused by the recent passive demonstration of sympa- thy on the part of the Syrian soldiers in Yemen. Wherefore the Government's vigilance has lately been redoubled, and a greater de- mand for the service of the spy manifested.

The Hamadé incident symbolises the wanton system of espionage by which the Govern- ment seeks to check the anti-Turk movement. Hamadé Bey, though a quiet, inoffensive and faitful Moslem, has been arrested chiefly because of his relationship with the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, the great exponent of Moslem liberalism. During his stay in Egypt as a zealous steamship agent he natur- ally endeavoured wherever he went to use all his persuasive powers to induce the Egypt- ians to pass the summer in the Lebanon. This laudable manifestation of a sense of duty was so distorted and misinterpreted by the salaried spies and calumniators of the capital that it ended by eliciting an impe- rial iradé of arrest. The officials charged with the communication of the order of arrest were friends of Hamadé Bey, and as the latter landed and greeted them with unsus- pecting friendliness they felt embarrassed and finally explained to him the position with the utmost kindness, while they led him off to the seraglio to undergo an interrogation and cross-examination at the hands of a committee formed ad hoc. In the meantime his luggage was seized and ransacked with diligent care, but the most obnoxious thing they could find was the well-known commen- tary on the Koran by the late learned Sheikh Mohamed Abdou. The Vali, a reasonable and well-meaning gentleman, did his best throughout to act in an equitable manner, but in delicate situations of this kind pru- dence sometimes dictates the sacrifice of cer- tain qualms of the conscience, and it is very doubtful whether the incident would have closed so happily with the relase of Hamadé Bey on the eighth day from his arrest, had not friends of the prisoner interceded successfully with the authorities at Constanti- nople.

div.head: (CYPRUS.) THE OLYMPUS HOTEL.
div.p: On Mount Troodos : 6,000 feet above sea level. Perfect climate. Magnificent scenery. Season May to October. For inclusive terms and information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, the General Manager, Cyprus Hotel Company, Limassol, Cyprus.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Rear-Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blom- field were among the passengers who arrived by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. Cleopatra this morning.
Owing to the postponement of the departure of the Moss boat, Mr. and Mrs. Gould will not leave for England till to-morrow.
Mr. F.G. Freeman, H.B.M.'s Vice-Consul, returned from leave on Saturday last.
Herr von Mohl, German Commissioner of the Public Debt, has arrived from Europe by the Italian mail. He is accompanied by Miss von Mohl.
Mr. C. Higgins, 3rd secretary to H.B.M.'s Agency, arrived from Cairo on Saturday.
We regret to announce the death, which took place on July 1 at Brockmeir-on-Wye, of the little daughter of Lt.-Col. Stanton, Go- vernor of Khartoum, who had twice been to Khartoum with her father.

We also regret to announce that Mr. Baehler, the well-known and popular manager of Shepheard's and the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, has suffered two terrible bereavements during the past week. His father died a week ago and at 10 a.m. yesterday Mme. Baehler passed away quietly at Leysin-sur-Aigle, Switzerland. Mr. Baehler's countless friends will join us in the expression of the most heartfelt sympathy for him in his double affliction.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. and Mrs. L. Zoucas and family, Mr. and Mrs. W. Page, Mr. and Mrs. H. Daffa and family, Mr. L.F. Limpritis, Mr. and Mrs. Marc Matatia, Miss L. Burell, Cav. and Mme. Ugo Luzzatto and family, Mr. E. Klein, Mr. L. Henein, Miss D. Bird, Miss M. Mewell, Mr. and Mme. I. Press and family, Mr. and Mrs. Th. Keill, Mme. Korsonsky, Mr. and Mrs. Nicolas Bey Bostros, Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Boyd Carpenter and fami- ly, Mr. and Mrs. E. Barozzi and family, Mr. and Mrs. L. Pally and family, Mme. Virginia de Castro, Mrs. T.H. Davies.

div.head: ARRIVALS.
div.p: Le paquebot "Cleopatra" du Lloyd Autri- chien arrivé ce matin de Gênes avait à bord: MM. Alderson, Major May, père Gabriel, père Haddad, Zoffrani, Hamilton, comte Wedel, Admiral Sir M. et Lady blomfield, D. Philipos- sian, Morgan, M. et Mme Calouta, M. et Mme I. Sachs, M. et Mme Aghion, Cosary, Perez, Baumann, Cohen, Stener, Fechet, S.E. Moh- Chaki Pacha et 3 de famille, Rosemberg, Koller, Mme Schindemann, Kroeger, Szarvasy, Pfeiffer, Smith et 2 filles, et 13 passagers de 3me classe.
